Message.Title: Intel - A Tap Dancing Mammoth - NOT
Message.Msg: Intel had been trying to tap dance in the mobile markets for more than 3 years now .... it's still a clumsy behemoth as seen by the latest benchmarking fiasco. Precious 14nm technology allocated for Low ASP Low Margin Mobile products is a winning strategy? The X86 architecture no matter how much they try to reinvent it is just plain inefficient in many ways. The new CEO will step down in 2 years if the board is doing their job - he oversold his strategy to get the job BUT nothing will happen since he is simply told them what they wanted to hear. Intel will shrink - not completely but it will. Nvidia had done a great job reinventing themselves and it helps tremendously that they are relatively small to start with. It's not completed yet but they are pretty close. Imagine 20% of intel revenue coming from mobile and tablets.

Message.Title: New York Times' David Pogue reviews OUYA (must read!, it's fun)
Message.Msg: SOURCE: NYTimes, July 17 The ending paragraphs: ""So yes, the company will spend the coming months running around stomping bugs, and game creators need time to dream up more offbeat winners. But already, Ouya is different, and entertaining, and portable, and open-source. And eminently entertaining and playable. Even at this, its never “finished” stage, it’s worth $100, especially if you don’t already own one of the more expensive consoles. Yes, ladies and gentlemen: the Corolla of game consoles has just pulled up."" ________ Google the title to access the original article: A Console With Quirks, for Tinkerers

Message.Title: "Settlement reached in NVIDIA Graphics Processing Units Class Action"
Message.Msg: "Settlement reached in NVIDIA Graphics Processing Units Class Action" " LONDON, ON, July 18, 2013 /CNW/ - A settlement has been reached with NVIDIA Corporation ("NVIDIA") in a class action lawsuit brought on behalf of Canadians who purchased a computer for use and not for resale equipped with a defective NVIDIA graphics card known as either a Graphics Processing Unit or a Media Communications Chip ("GPUs"). The proposed settlement is subject to court approval. Under the terms of the settlement, NVIDIA will pay CAD $1,900,000 for the benefit of those Canadians who purchased an "Affected Computer" that experienced a "Qualifying Symptom": (a) distorted or scrambled video on the computer screen; (b) no video on the screen even when the computer is on; (c) random characters, lines or garbled images on the computer screen; (d) intermittent video issues; or (e) failure to detect wireless adaptor or wireless networks. Not all computers contain the defective NVIDIA GPU. The exact dates of sale and qualifying symptoms vary by computer manufacturer. ..." source: newswire ca

Topic.Title: Toshiba Excite Pro (Tegra 4) is available on Amazon and BestBuy, NOW

Message.Msg: That's what I used to think. How can there be a big tablet market, when all that you can do is passively consume. You can't create. You'll sell a few, but won't change the world. It took me months to realize that I was wrong about it being a major market. Way more people have TVs than TV studios. Far more people have ipods than guitars. Content consumption is the major market. I was even wrong about them being useful tools. We are now in the early days of tablets becoming productivity devices. They make lousy keyboard, but OK keypads. They are good at checkbox lists, and excel at structured reports like home inspections where a mash-up of boilerplate text, a limited amount of new text and pictures are combined.

Message.Title: Qualcomm Thumps Chest About New Snapdragon 800, Claiming Tablet Dominance Over Intel
Message.Msg: SOURCE: Hot Hardware, July 18 Qualcomm’s Raj Talluri hasn’t been shy about talking up his company’s Snapdragon 800 chip, claiming back in February that it would whip NVIDIA’s Tegra 4 processor, and he’s back at it. This time, he’s dogging Intel. “You’ll see a whole bunch of tablets based on Snapdragon 800 in the market this year,” he told Bloomberg. “There’s a lot of talk about Intel and tablets. Clearly we see them still being far behind in mobile.” Them’s fightin’ words, as they say. He added that Qualcomm’s Snapdragon processors have a balance of battery life preservation and strong processing, communications, video, graphics, and more, which he says Intel doesn’t have. Of course, this is merely so much bluster at this point; neither Intel nor Qualcomm are exactly winning the mobile market. However, it’s good that they’re both making efforts in that vein, because juggernauts like Apple and Samsung could benefit from more competition. It’s also a little unusual for a company to talk this much trash publicly about a competitor--or should we say to a competitor--but it’s actually somewhat refreshing. The harsh words are a challenge, and when big companies challenge each other, they tend to make more competitive products, which benefits consumers in every way. Have at it, Raj. _______ It seems that the more QC does this kind of defensive talk, the more its stock falls.....look no further than today's trading.

Topic.Title: Intel - A Tap Dancing Mammoth - NOT

Message.Msg: Makes all the sense in the world. A tablet does not replace a high-end PC. It can replace a low-end PC. People who don't understand this don't understand why NVDA discrete is holding up okay. They also write articles like the amusing one I saw this morning supposing that INTC's pain opens up opportunity for AMD... opportunity when the part of the market that is their strength (low and mid) is the worst part of the market lately? Sigh.

Topic.Title: Intel - A Tap Dancing Mammoth - NOT

Message.Msg: Hopefully you aren't investing on the theory that x86 is somehow inherently inefficient. That doesn't hold much water based on research. So far, they have generally been used for less efficiency-critical parts, but it doesn't have to be that way. We'll see with Bay Trail. The signs this year are good. As for low ASP parts, you have to wonder about INTC's overcapacity at the moment. If they don't have some contract with Apple ready to go (I doubt that they do, but the rumors won't die, will they?) then there is little reason not to try to flood the market and take everyone else's margins. Might as well run over 90% capacity, right? If you can sell twice the goods at the half the margin, your accounts look the same. Everyone else's accounts, however... that is a different story. So, I wouldn't not look to INTC to leave their plants half-empty. IMO.

Topic.Title: Qualcomm Thumps Chest About New Snapdragon 800, Claiming Tablet Dominance Over Intel

Message.Msg: It amuses me that Qualcomm flexed its (yet to develop) muscles on tablet prowess. QC and friends could certainly learn a thing or two about how to get Win 8/8.1 drivers certified.

Message.Title: Microsoft off 5%. FY4Q rev, EPS misses
Message.Msg: From Barrons: Shares of Microsoft (MSFT) are down $1.70, or 5%, at $33.74, after the company this afternoon reported fiscal Q4 revenue and earnings per share well below analysts’ estimates, citing the impact of the decline in PC sales, but noting strength in corporate and cloud computing software.

Message.Title: AMD swings to loss
Message.Msg: MarketWatch just in: google the exact same title for article SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Chip-maker Advanced Micro Devices Inc. [s AMD] reported late Thursday a second-quarter loss of $65 million, or 10 cents a share, reversing a year-ago net profit of $37 million, or 5 cents a share. Adjusted to exclude one-time items, the company's second-quarter loss was $65 million, or 9 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter fell 18% to $1.16 billion from $1.41 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had expected the company to post an adjusted 12-cent per-share loss for the quarter on $1.11 billion in revenue. AMD shares were down 4.5% at $4.45 in after-hours trade. The stock is up 91% over the past 12 months.

Topic.Title: Microsoft off 5%. FY4Q rev, EPS misses

Message.Title: Analysts' responses to Intel earnings as per Barrons
Message.Msg: The bullish case: ---Ross Seymore, Deutsche Bank: Reiterates a Buy rating and a $26 price target. “ --John Pitzer, Credit Suisse: Reiterates an Outperform rating, and a $28 price target. ---Kevin Cassidy, Stifel Nicolaus: Reiterates a Buy rating and a $28 price target. The bearish case: ---Stacy Rasgon, Bernstein Research: Reiterates an Underperform rating and an $18 price target. ---Christopher Danely, J.P. Morgan: Reiterates a Neutral rating and cuts his price target a dollar to $18. ---Bobby Burleson, Canaccord Genuity: Reiterates a Hold rating and a $20 price target ---James Covello, Goldman Sachs: Maintains a Sell rating and a $16 price target. “Intel lowered its full-year forecast, and this is the fourth time in the last five quarters that Intel has guided out- quarter sales below the Street. We believe Intel has had to guide down so frequently because its full-year outlooks have been too high. We attribute this to management struggling to accept how cannibalistic tablets and handsets are to PCs. (2) Even though Intel guided down, we believe there is further risk. Intel’s implied 4Q13 sales growth is up 6-7% qoq, a number it has achieved only once in the last five years. (3) Intel’s implied 4Q13 gross margin guidance is flat to down, which we have long argued is the metric that the stock is best correlated with . We believe many investors were looking for sequential growth in margins for the rest of 2013 and into 2014, so even if Intel is able to hit its revenue targets, potentially lower margins will be a headwind. (4) We believe the stock is expensive, as it was already trading at 13X forward consensus EPS despite secular challenges, and Street estimates are likely to move lower post the call. As we have written previously, Intel would need to fully reset both its P&L guidance and spend significantly less on capex for us to be more positive.” _____ I include here only comments from GS because (like it or not) they have the most influence on market.

Topic.Title: AMD swings to loss

Message.Msg: A few key points: --AMD's graphic unit sales fell 5% in Q2, blaming it to market conditions. We shall find out how NV does to know the truth --AMD's growth margin fell to 39+% in Q2 2013, from 46% in Q2 2012. Pretty steep drop. --AMD stock fell only slightly because of Rory Read's promise of significant revenue growth in Q3 - meaning the shipment of parts to MS/XBOX One and to Sony/PS4. However, much of this has been factored into the current price according to several analysts.

Message.Msg: AMD Q2 earnings report says its Computing Solutions division sees unit shipments and ASP decline sequentially as well as year-over-year. Message.Title: Shield - hands on impression from the booth
Message.Msg: Went to Game Stop at Dolphins Mall in the Miami area to get a first personal view of the Shield (one of the few locations that has the Shield Booth) . The hardware is really solid and it feels overall really good. It was not as heavy as I thought. I asked the Game Stop staff whether there is a buzz around the shield... He said yes, but also that many have postponed actual purchases until the official release (and reviews), considering the 299 $ price tag.

Message.Title: Tegra 3 still bringing home the bacon, 18 months after its launch
Message.Msg: Some viewers may not be aware that Tegra 3 continues to power new tablets, phone, and console being introduced in the past 3-4 months. Its productive life is far from being over. Below is a short list of these new products - definitely not all inclusive: --OUYA microconsole - introduced in late June, 2013 --XOLO Play T1000 - introduced in July, 2013 in India for the mass market --Toshiba Excite Pure 7" tablet - introduced in US, Canada, Germany, France, UK last week, July 2013 --Hisense Sero 7" Pro - introduced in late May/early June, available at Walmart --Wikipad gaming tablet - refreshed version introduced in June, 2013 --Nabi XD 10" tablet - tablet for younger users, just received Editor's Choice Award from major tech site, -introduced in June, 2013 --ASUS memo 10: touchscreen tablet - introduced in June to global market (available at Walmart) Last, but not the least, Nexus is still entering new markets in devloping countries almost every month or every other month! I expect N7 will continue its popularity after N7 2 launch because of TegraZone and the device's gaming capability - cheaper too. This list also does not include the numerous white-box tablets being made and sold in China.
